SPOILS FRESHMAN PICTURE
First-Year Men,Posing for Class Picture
Are Drenched by Sophomore
Second-Story Men.

A sophomoric invasion succeeded
Thursday in routing the freshman
• class from its position on McCoy
Hall steps, and the Hullabaloo's
photographer was unable to record
for posterity the assembled likenesses of the first-year men.
Like the host of fallen angels
compared by Milton to leaves, locusts and several other things of
greater or less importance, the
Class of '18 was spread out in
lazy splendor on the Monument
street steps. In the foremost row
were the statesmen and athletes
whose importance was already becoming a matter of general knowledge and comment. Everybody had
shoulders thrown back—so serious,
so important. Peace reigned supreme. Suddenly the windows of
heaven (i. e., the German seminary)
opened and two buckets of water
descended or dashed (according to
the American's report of the matter) on the group of freshmen.
They were dazed awhile and a
few shivered and meekly they took
up another position on the steps ot
the physics laboratory. The sophs,
having succeeded in routing them
from one intrenchment, decided to
pursue. They got into the Physics
Building, but could find no water or
fire hose. They went to the windows directly over the steps, however, and gazing out saw that the
photographer's head had already retired beneath his cloth. Two of the
number whose voices were as the
belch of a "Busy Bertha" leaned
far out and exploded. The effect
was at once gratifying. It is said
that there were no serious casualties
in the mad scramble as the freshies
scampered from their positions.
A fight followed, the freshmen
accusing every sophomore they encountered. There were several '17
men standing about, and all pitched
in for a round or so. A bluecoated referee called the affair a
draw, and the battle was given up.
The classes then assembled for yells,
the cop coming in for a number of
daisies and las.
The sad detail has to be added
that the photograph of the freshman class was not taken, and unless
an arrangement for another "sitting" can be made, the Hullabaloo
will be without a picture. An
anonymous letter received by the
editor of the year book suggests
that instead of the picture, a drawing of the incident be used. This,
of course, will not be done if a
picture can be procured.
Iron Crosses will be awarded the
three enterprising sophomores who
conducted the rout.

BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 7, 1914.

HOW HOPKINS CAN HELP BELGIANS AND RED CROSS
The University Young Men's Christian Association and The NewsLetter Have Arranged to Receive Contributions of Money
and Clothing for the Belgians and to Roll
Bandages for the Red Cross.
Acting upon the belief that some
such movement for the relief of the
suffering Belgian people and the
supplying of the Red Cross organization with bandages, as has been
instituted in many of the leading
eastern universi ies, should be
brought to the attention of the
Johns Hopkins students, the University Young Men's Christian Association and THE NEWS-LETTER
have inaugurated a campaign for
the relief of suffering incident to
the war in Europe. For the success
of this movement they depend entirely upon the interest and enthusiasm manifested by the student
body.
The Young Men's Christian Association and THE NEWS-LETTER are
not rushing unaided into the field
of untried theory. Its plan of campaign, heartily endorsed by Miss
Mary B. Shearer, who is taking
such a prominent part in the local
movement for materially assisting
the destitute Belgians, is merely
that of urging the students at Johns
Hopkins to do what is already being accomplished in many smaller
and less influential institutions. Not
only will the city organization of
the Belgian Relief Society lend its
support and co-operation, but several members of the faculty are also
interested in the work and, by exercising their moral support, will aid
in bringing it to a successful issue.
The plan of campaign which has
been drawn up, and which will be
given in full detail in this article, is
arranged to meet the needs of the
Belgian Relief Society of this city.
The work at Johns Hopkins will
be in charge of a committee which
has already been appointed and
which will be entrusted with the
carrying out the details. All the
classes at the University are represented in this body, in order that
the interest in the new movement
which is being inaugurated may be
general, rather than confined to any
class, group or faction. Walter D.
Sutton, secretary of the Young
Men's Christian Association, is
chairmen of the committee and C.
Sewell Weech, J. S. Short, Thomas
J. Tingley, George D. Penniman,
Jr., J. Trueman Thompson and
Alexander Randall are the other
, members. These men will take
charge of the campaign and do their
utmost to secure the support of the
student body as a whole to assist
them in the enterprise.
The branch of the general movement which requires the co-opera-

tion of Hopkins students may be
divided into three distinct parts,
which will be dealt with separately.
The first aim of the campaign will
be to collect as many second-hand
suits or articles of clothing of any
kind as is possible, that they may
be sent to the Belgian refugees in
England. The support of these
wretched and destitute people is, of
course, a work that many wholehearted Americans consider their
work. The chief reason for sending the supplies to the refugees in
England, rather than to their 'even
more unfortunate fellow-countrymen across the Channel, however,
is that the Dutch government has
refused to allow any but new articles of wearing apparel to pass
through Rotterdam. The Maryland
ship Lynota, therefore, which will
leave for Europe on December 23,
will carry only unused garments to
the Belgians on the mainland, while
all second-hand clothing will be
sent to England at a later time.
The second aim of the campaign
will be to enlist the services of a
large • number of students for the
work of bandage-rolling. The secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association has offered the use
of Lever:ng Hall for this work,
which will be entered upon as soon
as possible. Material for the bandages will be supplied by the Belgian Relief Society of Baltimore.
It is hoped that a large number of
undergraduates will volunteer for
this branch of service, as the Red
Cross organization in Europe is being seriously handicapped in its
operations by lack of proper materials and general equipment. Not
only the larger and better-known
universities have already entered
upon this work, but several smaller
institutions in Maryland have taken
it up and Johns Hopkins surely
should not be content to remain ingloriously in the rear. The increasing spirit of progressiveness and
radical desire for growth and expansion, which have manifested
themselves at the University during the last few years, should ensure a ready and enthusiastic response to this call for assistance
in a work that aims to alleviate the
sufferings of the maimed and
wounded in all the armies at present
fighting in Europe.

FRESHMEN SWAMP SOPHOMORES
Captain Hoffman's Men Prove Superior
in Annual Game.

The prestige of the sophomore
class received a body blow at Homewood on Saturday, when the freshmen scored a decisive victory, 26-0,
in the annual interclass football
game. At no period of the contest
was the issue in doubt, for the
freshies scored in three of the four
quarters and completely outplayed
their opponents.
A remarkable feature of the
game was the apparent ease with
which each team advanced the ball
through the other's line. Neither
the sophomore nor the freshman
forwards seemed able to hold and
the result was a gain every time
the backs hit the line. The sophs
marched the whole length of the
field sev er al times; Mowbray,
Brooks and Captain Gorman tearing
large holes in the opposition. But,
when within striking distance, the
second-year men invariably fumbled
or attempted a forward pass and
thus lost all their chances to push
the ball across.
Bobby Hoffman, 'Varsity fullback and all-Maryland selection,
was the offensive and defensive
mainstay of the freshmen. He was
good for a gain whenever called
upon and it was his consistent
plunging and end running that won
the game for '18. On the first lineup, after the kick-off, he broke
through for forty yards, placing the
ball in a position from which it was
carried over for the first score in
three plays.
The scrap over the freshman banner was more interesting than the
game, however, and it resulted in
complete victory for '17. Today
many sophs are exhibiting bits of
blue silk and claiming that they
came from the ill-fated standard of
the other class. Whether the sophs
got the whole of the blue banner or
not is a question, but it is safe to
say that'what is left would not be
an adornment to a flag pole. Therefore, '18 has ordered a new and
handsomer flag, to be unfurled after
the interclass meet in January. The

COMING LECTURES OF INTEREST

DEBATERS CHOOSE A SUBJECT

Dates and Topic of Sir Walter Raleigh's
Series Announced—Owen Wister,
Novelist, Also Scheduled.

Council Selects Topic to Be Argued by
Class Men and Submitted to
Virginia and North Carolina.

Owen Wister, novelist, poet and
magazine writer, one of the bestknown of American authors, will
lecture under the auspices of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital Society on
"Superstitution and the Doctor" on
Monday night, December 14. The
talk will be given in McCoy Hall.
All who have read "The Virginian" and "Red Men and White"
will surely seize the opportunity to
see and hear the creator of these
popular books. Mr. Wister has a
markedly analytical power, and his
subject will undoubtedly give him
opportunity to express some interesting observations. Mr. Wister,
himself a lawyer, will speak of doctors and superstitions from a novel
point of view.
Mr. Wister graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law
School and began practice in Philadelphia in 1889. In two years,
however, he abandoned his profession for literary work, and has constantly been before the reading public in the magazines and in books.
He has a clever style, and has enjoyed wide popularity. He is a
member of the Board of Overseers
of Harvard University. One of his
books is ".Lady Baltimore."
The dates for the Turnbull lectures, which are to be given by Sir
Walter Raleigh, of Oxford, are
April 8, 9, 12, 13, 14 and 15. His
general topic will be "Poetry and
Criticism of the Romantic Revival."
Sir Walter graduated from University College, London, and from
King's College, Oxford. He has
taught at Liverpool and Glasgow,
and was called to the Cambridge
faculty in 1904. He is one of the
foremost living authorities on literature. He is the author of "The
English Novel," "Robert Louis Stevenson," "Milton," "Wordsworth,"
"Shakespeare," "Style," "The English Voyagers," "Six Essays on
Johnson" and many other articles.
Geheimrat Dr. Felix von Lushan,
professor of ethnography and anthropology in the University of
Berlin, will deliver two illustrated
lectures on "The Excavation of the
Hittite Capital" and "Anthropology
of Western Asia" in McCoy Hall
at 5 o'clock on December 14 and 15.
Dr. Von Lushan is one of Germany's authorities on his subjects.

At the second meeting of the
Debating Council, which was held
on Monday at one o'clock, arrangements for the annual inter-'varsity
and inter-class debates were made.
The contract agreed upon by
Johns Hopkins, the University of
Virginia, and the University of
North Carolina, when the triangular debating system was inaugurated, was endorsed for the present
year by a unanimous vote of the
Board, the only change being the
postponement of the date when the
three debates are to take place to
April 25, a week later than the
time set last year. It was decided to hold the try-outs for the
class teams before the Christmas
holidays, as the senior-junior set-to
is scheduled to take place some time
in January. Twelve o'clock on Friday, December i 1, the hour when
the junior class usually takes Forensics, was set as the time for the
contest among the third-year men,
while the try-outs for the team that
will represent the graduating class
will be held in the Donovan Room
at one o'clock on the following
Monday.
The main business before the
Council was the selection of a question to submit for the consideration
of Virginia and North Carolina.
For a long time it seemed that the
general subject of the advisability
of increasing the size of the standing army of the United States
would prevail in the selection, but
the question ultimately decided
upon was one favored by Professors
Barnett and Latane, and which is
of considerable present interest in
view of conditions in Europe. The
question to be submitted, and to
be dealt with by aspirants for places
on the class teams is "Resolved,
That the Policy of Colonial Expansion is Desirable for the Modern State."
In accordance with the formal
agreement between the universities,
each of the others will also select
a subject, and the question ultimately to be debated will be chosen
from among the three thus submitted. The subject of the juniorsenior debate will, in accordance
with Hopkins custom, be the same
as that decided upon by the universities for their verbal encounters.
To this wise custom, more than to
anything else, may be attributed the
unusual success of Hopkins representatives in the past, as most
of the men chosen had, in the
class debate, become thoroughly acquainted with every phase and with
both sides of the problem at issue.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 7, 1914.
LACROSSE MEN ORGANIZE

FEW TRACK STARS BACK

Large Number of Candidates Register and
Listen to Speeches by Tom Troxell,
Bill Schmeisser and Others.

Athletes at Organization Meeting Hear
There Will Be Many Vacant Places.
Over Fifty Candidates Register.

An unusually large number of candidates was present• at the lacrosse
organization meeting held Tuesday,
in the Trophy Room. This meeting marks the beginning of indoor
training for the 1915 lacrosse squad.
Veterans and new-comers listened
with attention to what Captain Tom
Troxell, the coaches and advisors
had to say concerning plans for the
coming season. Captain Troxell
opened the meeting with a short
speech, and after discussing the
schedule, said that there were unusually bright prospects for taking the championship banner next
spring. He introduced "Rainey"
Wolfe, who trained the Black and
Blue lacrosse players last year, and
who is at the head of the coaching department again this season.
Coach Wolfe centered his talk
mainly on freshmen, whom he
spoke of as "lucky," because they
had the chance of landing some of
the numerous places that are open
in the team this season. He pointed
out that there remain only two of
the defense men of last year, none
of the mid-field, and but four of
the attack men, and that all positions are undecided until the spring.
Other short talks were made by
Eddie Hulbert, Julian Marshall,
Mr. Clark, and Bill Schmeisser.
Pitts Raleigh and Bob Lowndes,
who were also on the program,
found, at the last moment, that they
would be unable to attend the meeting.
Julian Marshall and Eddie Hulbert were officially announced as
the assistant coaches for 1915.
These former Hopkins players told
the men of the hard work that is
ahead to win back the intercollegiate championship, and emphasized the fact that it is the work
at the beginning of the year in the
cage that counts.
Next, Bill Schmeisser, advisor to
the team, who has had 16 years' experience in lacrosse, and who is regarded as one of the leading authorities, on the game in America,
told of the merits of lacrosse. He
also pointed out that lacrosse is the
game that Hopkins is known by.
That no man who becomes interested in lacrosse will ever leave
the game is his firm conviction.
Captain Troxell has decided to
continue the excellent plan adopted
last year for the preliminary work
in the cage. It is his intention to
make a division in the squad—one
set practicing on Monday and
Thursday, and the other on Tuesday and Friday. Practice will begin at 4.45 o'clock. On Wednesday the entire squad will report in
the cage at four o'clock, and on
Saturday at 3.30 o'clock. This plan
of dividing up the squad will be of
great benefit to both the coaches and
candidates.

Over fifty men gathered in the
Trophy Room last Friday afternoon
to organize themselves into the
track squad for the coming indoor
and outdoor seasons. The situation is a most unusual one in that so
few of last year's point winners are
back in their old places. Only two
members of the relay team, which
defeated Virginia indoors and won
their event at the Penn Relays, are
back at the University. One of
them was hurt during the football
season, and the other, a graduate, is
so busy that it is doubtful whether
he will run. The squad as a whole
has suffered most severe losses, so
that the situation has only one parallel in the history of track at Hopkins—that of 1900-01.
In this year, however, a practically "green" team started on a path
of continuous victory which lasted
three years, and a relay team of
three freshmen and one upper classman was formed which scored fourteen victories and suffered but one
defeat in two years. A record was
smashed by this fast four which had
been considered almost "unsmashable," and the whole team broke
eight records in the course of its
bright career.
These astonishing results, as was
pointed out last Friday by Mr. England, the track coach, were due in
a very great degree to the spirit and
determination of the squad, which
faced the discouraging outlook with
real Hopkins spirit. Mr. England,
in speaking of this great opportunity now for new men, called attention to the fact that in a dual
meet there must be two or three
men entered in each of thirteen
events, making at least twenty-six
first-string men, and also three relay teams are to be entered at the
Armory meet. This shows bow
many places there are to work for.
Mr. England also thrilled the
hearts of the men by a vivid description of the two-mile race in
which Freddie Lee so covered himself with glory and brought cheers
for Hopkins from eighteen thousand throats at the Northern Intercollegiates last spring when he led
the field for over half the race and
finally finished in the first five in
this record-breaking event. With
such a picture as this before them,
the men who are facing the difficult
problem this year can have no lack
of inspiration.
Manager Deems reported that the
schedule will likely be very similar
to that of last year, although but
few dates are definitely set as yet.
It is planned to include the following:
Indoors—Armory Meet, George
Washington, Georgetown.
Outdoors—Navy, Penn Relays,
South Atlantic Intercollegiates,
Washington and Lee, Lehigh.

gallant action early in September
and was returned to his home.

sent to the Vosges Mountains into

I regret to say, that as far as
German universities are concerned,
your correspondent obviously is not
well informed. It can hardly be
said that the German universities
are deserted. Universities and technical schools are open as usual,

colors, a sufficient number (among
others, several thousand women students) remains to go on with lectures, seminaries and laboratory
work as usual. To the number of
existing universities a new one with
several hundred students was added
this autumn at Frankfort-on-theMain.
No one in Germany desired any
American students to leave the
country. On the contrary, they
were assured that they would be
as welcome as always. Among the
students that decided to remain in
Germany is a graduate student of
the Johns Hopkins University, Mr.
A. L. Taylor Starck, who is at present attending courses in German
philology at the University. of Berlin.
Yours truly,

street steps. In the foremost row

whose importance was already becoming a matter of general knowledge and comment. Everybody had
shoulders thrown back—so serious,
so important. Peace reigned supreme. Suddenly the windows of
heaven (i. e., the German seminary)
opened and two buckets of water
descended or dashed (according to
the American's report of the matter) on the group of freshmen.

having succeeded in routing them

Building, but could find no water or
fire hose. They went to the windows directly over the steps, however, and gazing out saw that the
photographer's head had already retired beneath his cloth. Two of the
number whose voices were as the
belch of a "Busy Bertha" leaned
far out and exploded. The effect
was at once gratifying. It is said
that there were no serious casualties
in the mad scramble as the freshies
scampered from their positions.

accusing every sophomore they encountered. There were several '17

picture can be procured.
Iron Crosses will be awarded the
three enterprising sophomores who
conducted the rout.

Owen Wister, novelist, poet and
magazine writer, one of the bestknown of American authors, will
lecture under the auspices of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital Society on
"Superstitution and the Doctor" on
Monday night, December 14. The
talk will be given in McCoy Hall.
All who have read "The Virginian" and "Red Men and White"
will surely seize the opportunity to
see and hear the creator of these
popular books. Mr. Wister has a
markedly analytical power, and his
subject will undoubtedly give him
opportunity to express some interesting observations. Mr. Wister,
himself a lawyer, will speak of doctors and superstitions from a novel
point of view.
Mr. Wister graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law
School and began practice in Philadelphia in 1889. In two years,
however, he abandoned his profession for literary work, and has constantly been before the reading public in the magazines and in books.
He has a clever style, and has enjoyed wide popularity. He is a
member of the Board of Overseers
of Harvard University. One of his
books is ".Lady Baltimore."
The dates for the Turnbull lectures, which are to be given by Sir
Walter Raleigh, of Oxford, are
April 8, 9, 12, 13, 14 and 15. His
general topic will be "Poetry and
Criticism of the Romantic Revival."
Sir Walter graduated from University College, London, and from
King's College, Oxford. He has
taught at Liverpool and Glasgow,
and was called to the Cambridge
faculty in 1904. He is one of the
foremost living authorities on literature. He is the author of "The
English Novel," "Robert Louis Stevenson," "Milton," "Wordsworth,"
"Shakespeare," "Style," "The English Voyagers," "Six Essays on
Johnson" and many other articles.

Berlin, will deliver two illustrated
lectures on "The Excavation of the

Dr. Von Lushan is one of Germany's authorities on his subjects.

At the second meeting of the
Debating Council, which was held
on Monday at one o'clock, arrangements for the annual inter-'varsity
and inter-class debates were made.
The contract agreed upon by
Johns Hopkins, the University of
Virginia, and the University of
North Carolina, when the triangular debating system was inaugurated, was endorsed for the present
year by a unanimous vote of the
Board, the only change being the
postponement of the date when the
three debates are to take place to
April 25, a week later than the
time set last year. It was decided to hold the try-outs for the
class teams before the Christmas
holidays, as the senior-junior set-to
is scheduled to take place some time
in January. Twelve o'clock on Friday, December i 1, the hour when

contest among the third-year men,
while the try-outs for the team that
will represent the graduating class
will be held in the Donovan Room
at one o'clock on the following
Monday.

Council was the selection of a question to submit for the consideration
of Virginia and North Carolina.
For a long time it seemed that the

would prevail in the selection, but
the question ultimately decided

agreement between the universities,

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 7, 1914.
LACROSSE MEN ORGANIZE

FEW TRACK STARS BACK

Large Number of Candidates Register and
Listen to Speeches by Tom Troxell,
Bill Schmeisser and Others.

Athletes at Organization Meeting Hear
There Will Be Many Vacant Places.
Over Fifty Candidates Register.

An unusually large number of candidates was present• at the lacrosse
organization meeting held Tuesday,
in the Trophy Room. This meeting marks the beginning of indoor
training for the 1915 lacrosse squad.
Veterans and new-comers listened
with attention to what Captain Tom
Troxell, the coaches and advisors
had to say concerning plans for the
coming season. Captain Troxell
opened the meeting with a short
speech, and after discussing the
schedule, said that there were unusually bright prospects for taking the championship banner next
spring. He introduced "Rainey"
Wolfe, who trained the Black and
Blue lacrosse players last year, and
who is at the head of the coaching department again this season.
Coach Wolfe centered his talk
mainly on freshmen, whom he
spoke of as "lucky," because they
had the chance of landing some of
the numerous places that are open
in the team this season. He pointed
out that there remain only two of
the defense men of last year, none
of the mid-field, and but four of
the attack men, and that all positions are undecided until the spring.
Other short talks were made by
Eddie Hulbert, Julian Marshall,
Mr. Clark, and Bill Schmeisser.
Pitts Raleigh and Bob Lowndes,
who were also on the program,
found, at the last moment, that they
would be unable to attend the meeting.
Julian Marshall and Eddie Hulbert were officially announced as
the assistant coaches for 1915.
These former Hopkins players told
the men of the hard work that is
ahead to win back the intercollegiate championship, and emphasized the fact that it is the work
at the beginning of the year in the
cage that counts.
Next, Bill Schmeisser, advisor to
the team, who has had 16 years' experience in lacrosse, and who is regarded as one of the leading authorities, on the game in America,
told of the merits of lacrosse. He
also pointed out that lacrosse is the
game that Hopkins is known by.
That no man who becomes interested in lacrosse will ever leave
the game is his firm conviction.
Captain Troxell has decided to
continue the excellent plan adopted
last year for the preliminary work
in the cage. It is his intention to
make a division in the squad—one
set practicing on Monday and
Thursday, and the other on Tuesday and Friday. Practice will begin at 4.45 o'clock. On Wednesday the entire squad will report in
the cage at four o'clock, and on
Saturday at 3.30 o'clock. This plan
of dividing up the squad will be of
great benefit to both the coaches and
candidates.

Over fifty men gathered in the
Trophy Room last Friday afternoon
to organize themselves into the
track squad for the coming indoor
and outdoor seasons. The situation is a most unusual one in that so
few of last year's point winners are
back in their old places. Only two
members of the relay team, which
defeated Virginia indoors and won
their event at the Penn Relays, are
back at the University. One of
them was hurt during the football
season, and the other, a graduate, is
so busy that it is doubtful whether
he will run. The squad as a whole
has suffered most severe losses, so
that the situation has only one parallel in the history of track at Hopkins—that of 1900-01.
In this year, however, a practically "green" team started on a path
of continuous victory which lasted
three years, and a relay team of
three freshmen and one upper classman was formed which scored fourteen victories and suffered but one
defeat in two years. A record was
smashed by this fast four which had
been considered almost "unsmashable," and the whole team broke
eight records in the course of its
bright career.
These astonishing results, as was
pointed out last Friday by Mr. England, the track coach, were due in
a very great degree to the spirit and
determination of the squad, which
faced the discouraging outlook with
real Hopkins spirit. Mr. England,
in speaking of this great opportunity now for new men, called attention to the fact that in a dual
meet there must be two or three
men entered in each of thirteen
events, making at least twenty-six
first-string men, and also three relay teams are to be entered at the
Armory meet. This shows bow
many places there are to work for.
Mr. England also thrilled the
hearts of the men by a vivid description of the two-mile race in
which Freddie Lee so covered himself with glory and brought cheers
for Hopkins from eighteen thousand throats at the Northern Intercollegiates last spring when he led
the field for over half the race and
finally finished in the first five in
this record-breaking event. With
such a picture as this before them,
the men who are facing the difficult
problem this year can have no lack
of inspiration.
Manager Deems reported that the
schedule will likely be very similar
to that of last year, although but
few dates are definitely set as yet.
It is planned to include the following:
Indoors—Armory Meet, George
Washington, Georgetown.
Outdoors—Navy, Penn Relays,
South Atlantic Intercollegiates,
Washington and Lee, Lehigh.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

SIR—In an article entitled "How
the European War Is Affecting
Oxford" in THE NEWS-LETTER of
November 30, 1914, I find the following paragraph:
"Needless to say, the German universities also are practically deserted. The natives are busy elsewhere,
students from hostile countries are
imprisoned and American students
have been sent out of Germany."
* *
I regret to say, that as far as
German universities are concerned,
your correspondent obviously is not
well informed. It can hardly be
said that the German universities
are deserted. Universities and technical schools are open as usual,
and while many of the German students of course have joined the
colors, a sufficient number (among
others, several thousand women students) remains to go on with lectures, seminaries and laboratory
work as usual. To the number of
existing universities a new one with
several hundred students was added
this autumn at Frankfort-on-theMain.
No one in Germany desired any
American students to leave the
country. On the contrary, they
were assured that they would be
as welcome as always. Among the
students that decided to remain in

FRESHMAN FEVER.

Freshman-Yet-a-Shade.

the Upper Classman said.
"What makes them look so white, so white?"
said Freshman-yet-a-Shade.
"They've been in g/m, they've been in gym,"

morning.

Freshman-yet-a-Shade.

said.

Freshman-yet-a-Shade.

- hadn't any space,

ligaments are tore,

generally sore,

European War,
So they're patchin' up the Freshmen in the
mornin'.
